title: 111_hr3099
content:
The Act may be cited as the "International Travelers Bill of Rights Act of 2009". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act, known as the "International Travelers Bill of Rights Act of 2009," defines key terms such as site operator, Commission, international travel services, overseas vacation destination, and United States. The term "United States" includes several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 3. Providing information on health and safety risks of overseas vacation destinations. A site operator must provide clear information on potential health and safety risks of overseas vacation destinations, including State Department travel warnings and onsite medical services available. The site operator must ensure that onsite health and safety services at overseas vacation destinations include trained personnel in CPR, an automated external defibrillator, and lifeguards for water-based activities. If services are not available 24/7, clear information on risks and available medical services must be provided. The site operator must display the hours and days of availability for onsite health and safety services on its website. If these services are not available at an overseas vacation destination, a clear message stating the lack of services and potential risks must be displayed prominently on the website. SEC. 4. CONSUMER COMPLAINTS.

A site operator must suspend an overseas vacation destination from its website due to consumer complaints about poor medical care, unsafe facilities, or health-related issues. Complaints must be made public on the website, with the option to modify or remove offensive content.

SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT.

Violation of this Act will be treated as a violation of unfair or deceptive practices under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Commission will enforce this Act with the same authority and regulations must be issued within 6 months of enactment.
